# prime
Fast generator of random big primes.

## Method

Program generates big (strongly probable) primes fast. It uses fragments of so called **prime DNA**,
sequence of *half the difference between two successor primes modulo 2*, as binary digits
of a big prime candidate being tested for primality.

Somehow it works much better than random or sequential search.

## Usage

```
USAGE:
    prime [OPTIONS]

OPTIONS:
    -d, --divisors <DIVISORS>    Order of the highest precalculated divisor prime [default: 100000]
        --debug                  Print debug information related to each tested span to stderr
        --descending             Start generating from bigger primes to smaller
    -e, --extra-tests            Perform extra tests (k-tuples, Cunningham)
    -f, --from <FROM>            Order of the lowest precalculated prime [default: 2]
        --final-strict           Perform final strict probable primality test on deduplicated primes
    -h, --help                   Print help information
        --magic                  undocumented, possible speedup
        --max-span <MAX_SPAN>    Maximal DNA fragment length [default: 255]
        --min-span <MIN_SPAN>    Minimal DNA fragment length [default: 255]
    -p, --power-2 <POWER_2>      Add extra power of two [default: -1]
    -t, --to <TO>                Order of the highest precalculated prime [default: 1000]
    -V, --version                Print version information
        --verbose                Immediately output probable primes to stderr, possibly duplicated
```

## Default

Default usage without any parameters is equivalent to calling:
```
prime --divisors 100000 --from 2 --to 1000 --min-span 255 --max-span 255
```
Timing on a personal laptop:
```
$ time ./prime
number of decimal digits bounds = (77, 77)
229	69	|prime|p(489,744,-1)	659369805580342958079426190346998501779269912019563319607871186186069

real	0m0.054s
user	0m0.226s
sys	0m0.010s
```

or e.g. with extra power of 2 added to the candidate primes:

```
$ time ./prime -p5000
number of decimal digits bounds = (77, 77)
4990	1502	|prime|p(620,875,5000)	
4996	1504	|prime|p(568,823,5000)	
4999	1505	|prime|p(433,688,5000)	
5001	1506	|prime|p(35,290,5000)	
Found 4 primes using 286 tests compared to 13855 expected tests. Speed-up 48.4Ã—.

real	0m6.365s
user	0m49.772s
sys	0m0.031s
```

## Benefit
I believe the observation of prime DNA could at least speed-up the collaborative efforts to generate largest known primes.

## Citing
Please cite this repo if you find the method useful for your research.
